bioghist.p: The Rosenbach Company was a Philadelphia firm dealing in rare books and manuscripts, and fine and decorative arts. The company was established by Abraham Simon Wolf Rosenbach and his brother Philip Rosenbach in 1903. Philip Rosenbach was elected president of the company and A.S.W. Rosenbach was elected secretary-treasurer. The company, with offices in Philadelphia and New York City, became recognized as one of the country's preeminent dealers in rare books and literary manuscripts, and A.S.W. Rosenbach is credited with helping build the collections of Harry E. Widener, J. P. Morgan, Henry C. Folger, and Henry E. Huntington. He also bought and sold some of the most famous literary manuscripts, including part of Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, Lewis Carroll's Alice's Adventures under Ground, and James Joyce's handwritten Ulysses (which he kept). A.S.W. Rosenbach died in July of 1952, Philip Rosenbach died in March of 1953, and the Rosenbach Company was closed. Both men left the bulk of their estates to the Rosenbach Foundation. The Foundation maintained the family house on Delancey Street in Philadelphia, and in 1954 opened the Rosenbach Museum and Library to preserve the Rosenbachs' collection of books, manuscripts, fine art, and antiques.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records of the Rosenbach Company from its establishment in 1903 to 1953, when the firm closed. Financial records include sales books, cash books, general ledgers, account books, accounts receivable cards, vouchers, bank statements, and check stubs. Records of the company's inventory include catalogues, bound and card-file listings of book and decorative arts stock, and volumes listing the items within particular collections. The collection also includes folders and scrapbooks of newspaper clippings on the Rosenbach Company and its purchases and sales, an album of photographs, and information on the Rosenbach Fellowship at the University of Pennsylvania.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
